Abizaid, said there was no need for more American troops, but encouraged Muslim allies like Turkey and Pakistan to send peacekeepers. He also said training of a new Iraqi Army should be accelerated.

U.S. Commander for Iraq Seeks More Muslim Troops The top American commander for Iraq, Gen. John P. Abizaid, said there was no need for more American troops, but encouraged Muslim allies like Turkey and Pakistan to send peacekeepers. He also said training of a new Iraqi Army should be accelerated.
A British soldier was killed and another injured when their convoy encountered an angry mob of Iraqis in southern Iraq after arresting two suspected loyalists to Saddam Hussein.
France, warning that the unstable situation in Iraq could fall into ''anarchy,'' called for formation of an international military force and a provisional government under United Nations authority.
Prime Minister Tony Blair said he would have resigned had there been any truth to a BBC report that his government had embellished an intelligence dossier on Iraq with dubious information.

Israel Reopens Holy Site Israel has opened to non-Muslims a site holy to three religions. Events surrounding the site provided what Palestinians consider the provocation and Israelis consider the pretext for the Palestinians' uprising, and many fear a backlash throughout the Muslim world.

North Korea's Nuclear Threat North Korea told diplomats from five other nations that it planned to declare formally that it has become a nuclear power and may test an atomic bomb in the near future to prove it, according to senior Bush administration officials.

Peruvian Death Toll Doubled The Peruvian government-appointed truth commission said 69,000 people were killed or disappeared between 1980 and 2000, more than twice earlier estimates of the toll for the decades of war and dictatorship.

Prosecutors Suspicious Of DNA Evidence Prosecutors across the country acknowledge that DNA testing is reliable, but they have grown skeptical of its power to prove innocence in cases where there was other evidence of guilt.

Female Cadets Tell of Rapes Nearly 12 percent of women who graduated from the United States Air Force Academy this year were the victims of rape or attempted rape during their four years at the academy, with the vast majority of them never reporting the incident to authorities, according to a survey by the Defense Department's inspector general.

Prison Policy Faulted John J. Geoghan, the defrocked pedophile priest strangled in prison by another inmate, was confined in the same protective custody unit as his assailant largely because the Massachusetts Department of Correction has only two protective custody units, lawyers and experts familiar with the case say.
Michigan Revises Admissions The University of Michigan unveiled a new admissions policy that preserves affirmative action but applies it less stringently to minority applicants.

New Voice for Unions The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced that it was creating a novel organization for nonunion workers who agree with the labor movement on many issues and want to campaign alongside labor on those issues.

E.P.A. Says It Lacks Authority The Environmental Protection Agency said it did not have the legal authority to regulate carbon dioxide and emissions of other heat-trapping gases under the Clean Air Act.

White House Calls for Reviews The White House budget office plans to require government agencies to employ independent experts to review the quality of scientific analyses used in developing regulations.

Port Authority Releases Sept. 11 Transcripts The Port Authority released more than 1,800 pages of transcribed radio transmissions from Sept. 11, 2001, much of them from dozens of people in and around the World Trade Center. The transmissions reflect the critical difficulties faced by those who survived the plane crashes, yet were unable to escape the buildings.

Free Tutoring Goes Unused A vast majority of New York City children who were eligible for free tutoring last year under a new federal law never got the extra help, and critics say there are few signs of improvement this year.

States Challenge E.P.A. Shift Environmental groups and state officials across the Northeast began preparing legal challenges after the Bush administration issued rules that will relax pollution-control regulations.
John Shearman A historian of Italian Renaissance art who advised on the restoration of Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican, he was 72.

Mercury in Fish Identified The kind of mercury found in fish has been determined for the first time, in a report that raises the possibility that the form found by researchers is less toxic than other kinds.
Demand for Surgery Soars American doctors and hospitals are scrambling to satisfy the booming demand for bariatric surgery to shrink the stomachs of severely obese people.

Economic Growth Picks Up The economy grew at a revised annual rate of 3.1 percent in the second quarter, as corporate profits jumped. The unexpected strength led economists to raise their forecasts for the rest of the year.
W.T.O. Nears Drug Plan A key committee of the World Trade Organization approved a plan to help poor nations buy generic medicines.
Slowdown in Travel Expected Long lines this Labor Day weekend are of little consolation to the weary travel industry, which is expecting another difficult autumn to follow.
